instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad SMC or CPU?
threads.message:
Currently working on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> where power supply is pulling .02Amps. Device has no signs of liquid damage. Always present power rails are present. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is present. <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is missing. Board does not boot in SMC Bypass. I discovered the tiniest amount of corrosion under SMC on Pad 64 which is <SIGNAL>SMC_PWRFAIL_WARN_L</SIGNAL>. Did not find corrosion anywhere else on board. I reflowed SMC to remove the corrosion and device still pulls .02Amps and does not boot in SMC Bypass. Before I spend the time pulling off SMC and Reballing, is this a sign of a dead CPU?

Sorry for the brief explanation.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad SMC or CPU?
threads.message: Try another SMC to be safe. If no change, could literally be anything including the CPU causing no S4. Inspect as closely as possible for corrosion elsewhere.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad SMC or CPU?
threads.message: Sounds good. Will follow up after SMC Replacement.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad SMC or CPU?
threads.message:
What about <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>?
Magsafe 2 charger for sure?

Check if <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>; use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads for this.
Be sure <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> is high.

Do you get <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>?
If not, check all PCH's RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad SMC or CPU?
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad SMC or CPU?
threads.message:
It took a while to revisit this board but I am back at it. I have not replaced the SMC yet.

Using both orginal 85 watt magsafe 2 and DCPS with genuine 85 watt magsafe 2 connector attached.
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drops from 3.4v to .04v when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3v

BATLOW = 0.037v

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is missing.

I see that BATLOW comes from SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad SMC or CPU?
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drops from 3.4v to .04v when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>"
Check if any <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signal reacts at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad SMC or CPU?
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> = Stays at 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = stays at 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = stays at 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> = stays at 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> = stays at 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad SMC or CPU?
threads.message: I removed the SMC and behold, there was a hole in the SMC. Image attached. I am replacing the SMC now to resolve issue.
